title: Meghan Markle news Prince Harry Royal tour Australia Melbourne Government House
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will start their itinerary on day three of their tour in the urban metropolis of Melbourne, where they will meet members of the public before being received by politicians at Government House.The Royal couple will meet youth leaders and community members during their reception at Government House, including those from This Girl Can and The Man Cave organisations.They will then tour a social enterprise cafe offering mentoring programmes to aboriginal youth.In the afternoon, the Duke and Duchess will visit a local primary school before travelling to south Melbourne via the city&rsquos famous trams in order to meet volunteers at a local beach patrol programme.&nbsp                What are the Duke and Duchess of Sussex doing in Melbourne TODAY?                Meghan Markle and Prince Harry Australia tour LIVEFollow below for live updates on everything that happens on day three of the Royal tour (all times in BST)&nbsp8.11am update: Harry spoke of fast fashion and its environmental impact as he and his wife took to the beach in MelbourneHarry and Meghan's last engagement of the day in Victoria saw them visit South Melbourne beach, where they heard about BeachPatrol's efforts to keep the local coastline litter-free and reduce the impact on the marine environment.Students from Albert Park primary school and Albert Park college - who had been helping to keep the beach tidy - showed the couple bags containing plastic cups, bottles and straws which they had found in the sand.The duke said: There is literally plastic everywhere. And, you know, microplastics are a real problem, especially the microplastics from fast-fashion. Did you know that's one of the biggest culprits?Meghan told the pupils: It's amazing what you guys are doing. Well done, you're doing a really great job. Keep it up.The couple then strolled hand in hand towards an assembled group of lifeguards with one, Sebastian Top, asking if they were going for a dip.Meghan, who was wearing eco-friendly shoes made from recycled water bottles by Rothy's,&nbsplaughed and replied: Maybe not today.Harry pointed to a group of around 30 people who had waded into the sea from the beach to get a better view of them.He said: If we try and swim, I think they might be a bit of a hazard.Meghan Markle and Prince Harry will visit Government House in Melbourne on Thursday (Image: REUTERS)Meghan Markle (Image: )7.56am update: Fit for a princess!&nbspMeghan was gifted a tiara during a visit to&nbspa Melbourne school.Harry and Meghan were met by 600 pupils at the Albert Park primary school where they learned about efforts the school is making to cut waste and be more sustainable.The duke picked out Annie from the crowd after seeing her holding a bunch of flowers and toy tiara.Are they for her?, Harry asked, gesturing towards his pregnant wife.Meghan then came over, took the gifts and said Oh my goodness, thank you. Those are amazing.Harry also raised a smile at the school when he was given the opportunity to name the pet snail, and suggested Speedy.As the couple left, one little boy told Harry: You remind me of my uncle.The duke replied: Is that a good thing? Is it because I've got a ginger beard?Rebecca Perring is now reporting&nbsp6.50am update:&nbspPrince Harry introduced to guide by Governor of Victoria&nbspThe Governor of Victoria Linda Dessau introduced Prince Harry to a guide dog during their reception at Government House in Melbourne.Mrs Dessau is a&nbsppatron of Guide Dogs Victoria.6.10am update:&nbspMeghan talks to kids on Melbourne beachMeghan and Harry spoke to local school children at South Melbourne Beach, to learn about how they are contributing to the clean-up operation of the city&rsquos beaches and waterfronts.The couple were gifted Beach Patrol T-shirts during their short stop, before they made their way back to the airport to return to Sydney.5.30am update:&nbspMeghan changes outfit ahead of beach visitMeghan changed out of her high heels and into flats ahead of her visit to South Melbourne Beach, where the couple met lifesaving volunteers and a beach rubbish collection organisation.South Melbourne Beach was the couple&rsquos last stop of the day before they return to Sydney.5.15am update:&nbspDuke and Duchess ride on Melbourne tramMeghan and Harry rode on Melbourne&rsquos iconic tram between Albert Park Primary school and South Melbourne Beach.Meghan Markle and Prince Harry rode on Melbourne's iconic tram (Image: )5.02am update:&nbspMeghan and Harry visit primary schoolMeghan and Harry visited Albert Park Primary School, where they met students and teachers.The Royal couple spoke with students in the school&rsquos &rsquoParadise&rsquo garden, where they learnt about environmental sustainability.4.31am update:&nbspThe Governor of Victoria delivers speech at Youth Leaders ReceptionThe Governor of Victoria Linda Dessau delivered a speech at the youth leaders reception at Government House in Melbourne.She thanked Meghan and Harry for their visit, and said it had been a catalyst to acknowledge the talent of various social enterprise groups.&nbspShe said: &ldquoWe thank Your Royal Highnesses, whose visit has been the catalyst to gather this talent, and this promise, with us today at Government House.&ldquoYou have already met some of our brightest innovators, and some of the women who, through the &lsquoThis Girl Can&rsquo campaign, so ably display the strength and resilience built on a healthy and active lifestyle.4.05am update:&nbspMeghan and Harry eat chargrilled kangaroo and wild boarMeghan and Harry visited a social enterprise cafe in Fitzroy, Melbourne, where they learnt about how the organisation is helping to support young indigenous people.They enjoyed a menu which included mushroom and quinoa nest with chargrilled kangaroo, wild boar, saffron risotto and barramundi.Prince Harry met a baby during a walkabout outside Government House (Image: )3.50am update: Meghan and Harry visit Charcoal Lane for lunchMeghan and Harry arrive at Charcoal Lane in Fitzroy for lunch.The couple viewed a mural designed by Aboriginal wrist Robert Young.3.25am update:&nbspMeghan shocked by demonstrationMeghan received a shock during a demonstration by the F1 in Schools team at a reception in Government House.The Royal couple got to race two mini F1 cars set up on a track on the state dining room table.Pupils from Trinity Grammar forgot to tell Meghan that a loud noise would be generated when they started the race.Meghan appeared surprised and doubled over with laughter.3.05am update: Meghan takes part in demonstrationsMeghan took off her trench coat and got involved in the demonstrations put on by ambassadors from the This Girl Can campaign.The Duchess was seen throwing an American football to others participants.Meghan Markle and Prince Harry greeted fans when they arrived in Melbourne (Image: )2.25am update:&nbspMeghan met members from This Girl Can programmeMeghan and Harry met representatives from the This Girl Can programme, which aims to get women involved in sport.The Royal couple watched a demonstration from participants of the programme, which included a series of exercise routines suitable for women of all ages.The gardens of Government House were converted into an outdoor gym for the demonstration, with exercise bikes, basketball nets and yoga mats.2.05am:&nbspMeghan and Harry arrive at Government HouseMeghan and Harry arrived at Government House following their walkabout greeting the public.They are attending a reception with young leaders hosted by the Governor of Victoria, Linda Dessau, who met the pair at the entrance of the building.1.50am update: Meghan opts for Australian designers&nbspMeghan opted to wear a navy blue dress by Australian designer Dion Lee for the third day of her 16-day tour.She was also wearing a camel-coloured trench coat by Martin Grant.One Royal spectator admitted to skipping school in 1983 when Prince Charles visited Australia (Image: )1.30am update: Prince Harry and Meghan greet Royal spectatorsPrince Harry and Meghan greeted crowds of Royal spectators during a walkabout before arriving at Government House.The walkway was lined with armed police.1.17am update: Rain to dampen affairs on ThursdayHarry and Meghan will face downpours on Thursday, as rain clouds approach Melbourne.&nbspKeris Arndt, senior forecaster at the Bureau of Meteorology, said: &ldquoThere will be some showers around at 1pm, just enough to make people damp.The Duke and Duchess were drenched on Wednesday during a public picnic at Victoria Park in the regional town of Dubbo in New South Wales.Meghan was forced to hold an umbrella over herself and the Prince, while Harry delivered a speech to the crowd.12.46am update: Meghan and Harry arrive in MelbourneMeghan and Harry arrived in Melbourne after their aeroplane touched down following a one-and-a-half hour flight from Sydney.&nbspThe couple will travel directly to Government House.&nbspMeghan Markle and Prince Harry are visiting Government House in Melbourne on Thursday (Image: WIREIMAGE)Crowds gathered prior to the much-anticipated arrival of Meghan and Harry in Melbourne (Image: WIREIMAGE)12.30am update:&nbspRoyal spectator arrested in MelbourneA man was arrested by police and put in handcuffs at the Royal Botanic Gardens in Melbourne on Thursday morning.He was escorted away from the crowd of Royal spectators by police.12.25am update:&nbspMeghan and Harry spotted wearing matching outfitsMeghan and Harry were spotted wearing matching outfits when they boarded their flight for Melbourne from Sydney airport.Prince Harry was wearing a dark navy suit, while Meghan donned a navy, sleeveless dress and black heels.11.42pm update: Meghan and Harry depart for MelbournePrince Harry and Meghan Markle departed Sydney and boarded a flight for Melbourne.They were spotted earlier in a motorcade travelling from Admiralty House in Sydney to the airport.The flight duration between Sydney and Melbourne is roughly one hour thirty-five minutes.

title: Brexit news The Who Roger Daltrey UK EU withdrawal British music Bob Geldof latest
story: The Who frontman mocked colleagues like Bob Geldof and Ed Sheeran for joining forces to warn about the risks Brexit poses for the British music industry,Mr Daltrey trashed claims failing to secure a deal with the European Union would be reckless and threaten the cultural role the UK has carved for itself on the international stage.Speaking to the Today programme, he said: It&rsquos nothing that can&rsquot be solved. I mean, we used to work in Europe before Europe was even thought about, or the EU was even thought about.We had the golden period of the 60s and the 70s. I&rsquom not against Europe at all. It&rsquos Brussels &ndash&nbspthere are far too many people on far too many gravy trains soaking us dry.                Sting and Ed Sheeran JOIN Bob Geldof's latest anti-Brexit attack                Farage RIDICULES Bob Geldof's latest 'hysterical' ATTACK on BrexitThe Who founder lamented the democratic deficit of the EU, complaining about the lack of direct interaction between EU voters and the institutions.He continued: I&rsquove been very much in favour of Europe, I was very much in favour of the economic community but I was always, and have always been, against the construct of Brussels. I think it&rsquos a disaster.The construct of Brussels and the democratic deficit of it.&nbspThere's&nbspno direct link between the voter, and to get through to those people that run our lives, and there&rsquos far too many people on far too many gravy trains soaking us dry.Asked about possible complications for British artists to organising tours in Europe, Mr Daltrey appeared unphased.Brexit news: Daltrey rejected claims leaving the EU is bad for British music (Image: )He added: We did it in those days, it might be a bit more paperwork on this side of the Channel. I&rsquom sure they can make it hard if they want to but these things work both ways.Jarvis Cocker, Brian Eno, Damon Albarn, Johnny Marr, former The Smiths guitarist, and Pink Floyd's drummer Nick Mason have also joined forces in the anti-Brexit campaign.Launching his campaign in early October, Mr Geldof said: It's two-fold. One is the income it generates for this country, &pound94bn, contrast that to the NHS spend, of &pound115bn, almost the same.This will be critically damaged. The second reason is cultural - the voice of Britain, the genuine, global British voice is music, it has been since the Beatles.No one knows quite why this tiny island produces such vast reservoirs of talent but we do know the entire planet dances, eats, sleeps, and plays hard to our noise.That is being endangered by a recklessness which is existential and historically self-damaging.

title: Brexit news Henkel Donald Tusk UK EU withdrawal new deal border control latest
story: The German politician urged the top Eurocrat to offer Britain a new arrangement putting an end to freedom of movement, suggesting the change in strategy could stop Brexit.Mr Henkel implored Donald Tusk to step over his own shadow to reach a satisfactory withdrawal agreement with the UK &ndash claiming the end of free travel between the European Union and the UK might convince Brexiteers to backtrack on plans to leave the bloc.Speaking to Sky News, the German MEP said: President Tusk talked about a Gordian knot and he is right. I appeal to Mr Tusk to behave like Alexander the Great. He should cut this Gordian knot, he should step over his own shadow and offer Britain now a different solution when it comes to freedom of movement.This is either good for a better deal under the assumption of Brexit but it would also be good in case Britain changes its mind. Even the Brexiteers could then say &lsquook, we got what we always wanted without the disadvantages of Brexit.                Italian diplomat demands Britons 'satisfy EU needs' in heated TV clashMr Henkel insisted Brussels should stop behaving unreasonably and arrogantly, providing Britain with an alternative arrangement which would justify a new vote on membership to the EU.He continued: The European Union is behaving unreasonably at times and I think, sometimes, very arrogantly. In this particular case, however, I don&rsquot see any real solution.My suggestion is the Commission stops linking trade always with freedom of movement, offers Britain a new deal and then give Britain the chance to rethink their decision.The German politician also rejected plans set forward by EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier to extend the Brexit transition period to December 2020.Brexit news: Mr Henkel implored Mr Tusk to offer Britain a new deal on freedom of movement (Image: SKY NEWS&bullEBS)Mr Henkel added: Extending that period by another year does not help. What would help is right now, if there was no deal by tomorrow and the next two weeks, the European Union offers Britain more time to negotiate.In other words, don&rsquot take this date of March 2019 too seriously. Give them a little bit more time to come up with a deal.Delay Article 50 because that is better than a no deal Brexit. No deal Brexit would be a total disaster for both, Britain and also the European Union.Mr Tusk revealed negotiations have become &ldquomore complicated than was previously predicted as both sides reach yet another impasse on the Irish border conundrum.The warning came in his invitation letter to European leaders, who will gather in the Belgian capital on Wednesday evening for crunch discussions about the United Kingdom&rsquos orce from the EU.Negotiations are currently &ldquopaused as both sides struggle to agree on the highly disputed Irish backstop, according to a senior EU diplomat.

title: Brexit news Theresa May SNP Nicola Sturgeon fisheries UK EU Scotland withdrawal latest
story: The Prime Minister swiftly rejected Mr Blackford's demands, pointing out her proposed Brexit deal would protect the interests of all citizens across the country.Mrs May suggested the SNP join the Government into putting an end to the rule of the European Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) if they are interested in safeguarding the livelihoods of Scottish workers.Exchanging barbs with the SNP MP during a heated PMQs session, the Prime Minister said: As I have explained to this chamber on a number of occasions and will continue to do, the proposal we have put forward is one that delivers on the referendum but also ensures we protect jobs and livelihoods across the United Kingdom.But if the Right Honourable Gentleman is interested in ensuring the interests of everybody in Scotland are taken into account, he should join with us in recognising the importance of leaving the Common Fisheries Policy.                French fishermen could CLASH with British boats after Brexit                British fishing FIGHTS BACK with defiant message for &lsquosinking&rsquo EUThe Scottish National Party has made no attempt to disguise their dissent with Brexit, recently suggesting the party could support calls for a second referendum if connected to a new vote on Scottish independence.&nbspQuestioning Mrs May, Mr Blackford said: Prime Minister, go to Brussels and act in the interest of all citizens across in the UK and negotiate to keep us in the single market and customs union. That will command a majority in the House of Commons.Does the Prime Minister not understand that staying in the single market and the customs union is the only deal that will get through this House?Despite voicing opposition to the CFP and it granting permission to EU vessels to catch fish in British waters, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has remained an outspoken critic of Brexit &ndash going as far as suggesting Scotland be allowed to stay in the single market in 2017.Brexit news: Theresa May called on the SNP to join the Government to get Scotland out of the CFP (Image: PARLIAMENT TV)Research from Kent&rsquos School of Anthropology and Conservation suggested the CFP harms fishing communities' livelihoods and put their survival at risk, while in turn making the rich richer.Professor Douglas MacMillan, one of the researchers taking part in the study, said the CFP focuses too much on fish stock conservation and has no meaningful policy regulations to ensure that quotas for over-fished stock such as tuna are equally shared amongst fishermen.He said: &ldquoThis allows inidual nations to implement their own policies, which more often than not are captured by local elites to enhance their wealth and power through, for example, capturing all the quota.&ldquoFurthermore, additional conservation measures such as no-fishing zones are crude and tend to curtail all fishing activity over large segments of coastal waters, regardless of whether the fishing undertaken there is sustainable or not.British fishermen believe UK waters are overfished by other EU countries and the CFPmeans they are also restricted as to how much they can fish. The strict EU regulations mean that some British fishermen are forced to throw fish back into the sea.

title: Scrapping free TV licence over 75s cruel
story: More than 4.46 million homes with older residents receive a free TV licence, saving them &pound150.50 (Image: Scott BarbourGetty Images)A discussion paper commissioned by the BBC has described the concession as no longer justified as the wealth of over-75s had improved significantly.It insisted there had been profound economic changes since the benefit was introduced and noted that pensioners are now the least likely age group to live in poverty.But the proposal prompted widespread and immediate criticism from campaigners and charities who pointed out that many older people live in poverty and rely on their televisions to combat loneliness.Latest figures show 1.9 million pensioners still live in poverty &ndash including nearly one in five over-75s.                Woman, 86, suffers heart attack after purse snatched from bag in sh...As many as 3.6 million older people in the UK live alone, more than two million of whom are 75-plus, and one in four older people views the television as their main form of companionship.Dame Esther said: The Silver Line receives thousands of calls from older people through the evening, especially on long winter nights when the TV is their only friend.They have paid the licence fee all their lives &ndash this is the way the BBC can give something back.National Pensioners Convention general secretary Jan Shortt called on the Government to take the licence concession back in-house.Miss Shortt said: Ever since George Osborne forced the BBC to take over responsibility for the free TV licence, we have known that they would try and get rid of it.Dame Esther Rantzen campaigns for older people (Image: Jeff SpicerGetty )Frankly it's not the job of the broadcaster to administer or fund part of our wider welfare policy. That is a job for government and it needs to be returned to the most suitable department as a matter of urgency.Laura Alcock-Ferguson of the Campaign to End Loneliness, said: Television provides a great comfort for many lonely older people.It can give structure and routine and make you feel as though you're part of something. The prospect of that being taken away could have a devastating impact on older people experiencing loneliness.More than 4.46 million homes with older residents receive a free TV licence, saving them &pound150.50 a year.But the BBC is reported to be preparing proposals on reforming the subsidy, which could include raising the age of eligibility and means-testing.Options could also include asking for voluntary payments and removing the subsidy from pensioners who live with younger family.The report by Frontier Economics, on behalf of the BBC, says by 2022 the cost to the corporation will be &pound745million - more than double the &pound365million paid by the Government in 2002.Former Labour business minister Ian Lucas yesterday urged Theresa May to halt any cuts. The Prime Minister said it was up to the BBC to take a decision about how they operate on this.The broadcaster's report says when the concession was introduced, it was justified based on evidence that older pensioner households were disproportionately concentrated at the bottom of the income distribution.It also says: Incomes, wealth and life expectancy of older people have improved significantly. Pensioner poverty rates have fallen, and older households report higher wellbeing on a range of metrics.These changes give cause for reflection on what an appropriate approach to providing concessionary licences to older households might look like.A BBC spokesman said: There are important issues to consider. We will do nothing without consulting with the public. title: what brexit backstop plan theresa may eu irish border
story: Heres our guide to the plan and what it means for Northern Ireland and its border with the Republic of Ireland.The backstop plan is essentially a safety netthere is no Brexit trade deal.It sets out a list of proposals for customs arrangements with the EU in case a permanent deal is not secured by March , when the UK is due to leave the EU.Prime Minister Theresa May secured approval from senior ministers for the arrangement that could keep the UK in a customs union with the EU beyond the end of .It would ensure that no tarfs, quotas, rules of origin or customs processes would be applied to UK-EU trade.At the same time the UK would be able to strike free trade agreements with other countries.The EU has suggested a backstop that would see Northern Ireland staying in the customs union, the EU VAT system and parts of the single market.This will essentially draw a customs border down the middle of the Irish Sea. potentially damaging the union of the UK.Mrs May has suggested a backstotp that will see the all of the UK aligned with the EU customs union for a limited time after .Brussels has two issues with Mays plan.The first is that May wants the backstop to come to an end after a certain time period the EU think this would be self-defeating as its possible no solution for the Irish border would be found.The EU also thinks this risks leaving Britain benefiting from the customs union and single market for years after Brexit - reaping all the benefits without having any of the obligations that full membership would entail.In June  European leaders said Britain was running out of time to do a deal because of the unsolved border problem.In July Theresa May quoted Shakespeare as she insisted the UK would not be broken up with a border down the Irish Sea.Theresa May has told EU leaders she is looking at ways of keeping Britain under their rules for at least another year as part of efforts to break the Brexit deadlock.Addressing the  national bosses at a tense summit in Brussels on the night of October , the PM said she is “ready to consider” extending the  month transition period after the UK leaves the EU next March.The potentially incendiary move has been drawn up by the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier to try to end a bitter impasse over the Irish border.It would mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest.The news comes after talks on Sunday, October  hit a brick wall once again, as the issue of the Irish border continues to cause a headache for Theresa May.Theresa May has insisted any backstop arrangement must apply to the UK as a whole so not to create a border in the Irish Sea.However, Sundays talks broke down after the EU had insisted on a second backstop arrangement - just involving Northern Ireland -the UKs version wasnt ready in time, according to Downing Street sources.The Democratic Unionist Party has vowed to oppose any new checks on goods passing between Great Britain and Northern Ireland.Irelands Foreign Minister, Simon Coveney, suggested a deal would not be done at this weeks summit, which starts on Wednesday.Mr Coveney said he was frustrated and disappointed that it was going to take more time than people had hoped.

title: men stop chatting up schoolgirls
story: The figures come from a report by children’s charity Plan International UK, which also found two-thirds of girls say they have experienced unwanted sexual attention in public.A third of girls have been touched, groped or grabbed by men they don’t know. This kind of thing is so commonplace that many — some as young as eight — feel street harassment is “part of growing up”. How awful is that  Partly, the problem is that somewhere along the line, the idea that schoolgirls are “sexy” has become normalised, acceptable, even mainstream.Yes, I know that the waters were somewhat muddied by the likes of Britney Spears in her Baby One More Time video and Gemma Arterton in her St Trinian’s films — both looking as sexy as heck in school unorm.  And yes, I know a lot of girls look older than they are, and might even try to do so by wearing make-up, smoking or shortening their skirts on the way to and from school.But let’s be really clear about this. — girls young enough to wear school unorm are children. And the idea of any man thinking it’s OK to wolf-whistle, chat up or give any kind of sexual attention to a girl in a unorm is not just seriously worrying. It should be a criminal offence.By the way, I wonder what a similar survey of boys would find. Because the thought of women wolf-whistling schoolboys in the street is unimaginable, right  Parents of ­secondary school children need to give them some freedom to help them on the path to adulthood.Often, that involves letting them walk unaccompanied to school.  But the idea that doing that is exposing their child to the possibility of sexual harassment will be pretty distressing to any parent.One of the saddest things about this report is how many of the girls interviewed thought this kind of behaviour is “normal”. One -year-old said she felt street harassment was part of the “bro culture” and her dad had told her: “You know what men are like.”  What kind of advice is that for your daughter Another girl, aged , said: “It’s just become normal.” But the net result of behaviour like this is that it makes girls scared of walking the streets.All too often, our response to such news is to try to protect girls by telling them not to look too ­provocative. But that just perpetuates the idea men “can’t help themselves” so it’s down to the girls, and the way they dress, to make sure they are left alone.You can’t blame girls or women for men’s behaviour, no matter what theof their skirt. But the dficult truth is that we know women do have to ­mody their behaviour, and the way they dress, to stop men from ­commenting on their appearance, harassing them or worse.Perhaps what I am most shocked about is the young age at which this starts. One good thing is that these days, girls at secondary school have phones. They can record things that happen to them and report it. Also, Plan International UK is calling on bystanders to challenge harassment when they see it.Certainly,I was around someone wolf-whistling schoolgirls, I’d flip my lid. I would not be too scared to speak my mind and verbally intervene. I think my opening ­gambit would be: “How would you feelthat were your sister, ­granddaughter or daughter some old git was harassing ”To any man reading this who thinks it’s OK to talk to schoolgirls like this, let me tell you some of these girls are terried. It’s not funny or cute. It’s threatening. Lots of teen girls look older than they are butyou are confused and in doubt, here is a clue: The school unorm is a giveaway.Any man who leers at a child in a unorm is nothing short of ­disturbed. Andthey can’t stop themselves from doing so, the law needs to intervene.AS you know, I’m a huge advocate of body acceptance and self-love but I confess to a moment of envy at model Rachel McCord’s fantastic figure.Yes, clearly she must spend most of each day at the gym . . . But you have to give credit where credit is due. And she looks amazing!ANOTHER day, another crazy promise from Labour. This time it was Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell saying a Labour government would bring in a four-day working week.This, as Treasury analysis shows, means Labour would have to borrow £trillion to bankroll its spending spree over the next ten years – the equivalent of £, for every UK household. Frankly,the Labour Party gets into power, it will end up being a zero-day week as business will collapse and there will be no jobs to go to. The simple fact is you can’t run a country or a business on a four-day week.I LOVE a good party as much as the next person.But I can’t be the only person who rolled my eyes at the claim that Coldplay frontman Chris Martin and actress Dakota Johnson hosted a “baby gender reveal party” on Sunday.Apparently, large arches of pink and blue balloons were spotted flying above a star- studded bash at Martin’s Malibu home. Moments later, blue balloons were freed into the air, presumably announcing a baby boy is on the way.The couple claim it was just her birthday party but the singer did help introduce us to the term “conscious uncoupling”. Stand by for this being a new thing . . .She was being “punished” for running away with her Hindu boyfriend.Police were reportedly called to the scene but did not make any arrests – which beggars belief, doesn’t it Stories like this are a reminder that religion can be a negative power as well as a positive.I COULDN’T agree more with Sir Anthony Seldon, above, Buckingham University’s vice-chancellor, who wants the uni to adopt an actively anti-drugs stance.My son is at Buckingham uni and they already have snfer dogs all around campus, randomly checking students. Sir Anthony says he wants to create a “psychological contract” between students and the university so undergraduates implicitly agree to shun drugs when they enrol, which I think is a brilliant idea.His approach is the opposite to Sheffield University, where the student union gave advice on how to take ious hard drugs safely. But the fact is drugs aren’t safe and they ruin lives.  Barely a week goes by without another drug death appearing in the news.Some might say a drug-free campus is unrealistic. And sure, you probably can’t stop everyone taking them.  Nor can you prevent people wanting to experiment.  But making young people really aware that drugs are not only dangerous but illegal can only be a good thing.A WRITER called Kamin Mohammadi had an Instagram rant about “manspreading” this week. And yes, I know this happens. But I think we’ve got to get better at politely asking people to just stop it.Forget gender for a moment. I think it comes down to respect: It’s just blatantly rude to invade someone ’s space and the answer, in my view, is to call the person out.  If someone’s arm is on my arm rest on a train or plane, I ask them – in the nicest possible way – to move it.Let’s not be embarrassed when it’s someone’s legs.My personal bugbear is backpacks. I called a man out for keeping his on while on a crowded Tube train this week and he was really apologetic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit is worst defeat since 1066
story: As negotiations flicker to a halt, it seems Brexit actually means abject surrender, taking orders from Brussels and standing mute as the Council of Europe assumes control of our economy. We risk being sold down the river.Barring a last-minute revolt by Tory Brexiteers, Brussels has won and we have lost. The world’s sixth-largest economy will not just be worse off outside the EU, but reduced to a powerless political pawn on its margins — and paying for it.Sniggering can be heard across the capitals of Europe, with France guffawing loudest. The British Lion is a toothless kitten and we are the laughing stock of Europe.Unless stopped by her Cabinet, her MPs or by Parliament itself, this Prime Minister seems to be leading us to the greatest defeat since the Norman Conquest in , the last time we capitulated to a foreign power.The ransom demanded for our degrading humiliation — £BILLION of taxpayers’ money — is merely a down payment. The botched Chequers deal will bind this country in subordination to Europe.Forget about becoming a sovereign, free-trading nation. We will accept EU rules indefinitely while having no say at all in their terms or conditions. In effect, our economy will be run by Brussels, not by our democratically elected government.For an example of missed opportunities and failed leadership, this beats even last year’s election disaster, which wasted the first Tory majority for  years and put Marxist Labour within grasp of power.Worse, it now seems the PM’s apparent last-ditch capitulation was stitched up months ago behind closed doors after a dodgy threat by car giants to leave the UK.Now the Tory party is in uproar, with cries for a leadership contest. Downing Street is stupidly threatening a snap election. Nobody buys that except Jeremy Corbyn, who is licking his lips at the scent of power. Ministers, like frogs in a pot, are sizing up whether to jump or stew. Careers will be made or broken.At least three — and maybe six — are threatening to quit at tomorrow’s Cabinet unless Theresa blinks. Tory MPs are close to triggering a leadership fight, with sketchy plans for a quick and ruthless contest. “We have the numbers,” says one Tory MP.“If anything the mood is hardening, not softening.”Ex-Brexit secretary David Davis, the first rebel to quit Cabinet, will certainly run, infuriating Boris Johnson, who thinks it should be him. Once the gun is fired, half the Cabinet and plenty of hopefuls will join in.Everyone deserves blame, including Brexiteers who assumed the game was over after their victorious out vote and abandoned the field. Remainers are at fault for refusing to accept the will of the people — and the shortcomings of their beloved EU.But it is Downing Street, and Theresa May personally, who must take responsibility. Mrs May has dreamed of being Prime Minister since she was a child.It’s a tough job. It means leading from the front, making swt decisions and rallying the country with confidence and authority in dficult times.Instead, Mrs May’s team talk like defeatists about parliamentary “arithmetic”. How can she push through a dficult Brexit against ferocious opposition without a commanding Commons majority  But who was responsible for that parliamentary arithmetic It was Theresa May alone who decided to call an unforced election and it was she who single-handedly blew it. Her only task was to deliver the referendum mandate handed to her by .million voters. She blew that, too.People knew the risks. They did not vote for us to stay half-in, half-out or to see our sovereignty handed over to foreign powers. To govern is to decide. Mrs May made a career out of being the strong and silent type.Many of her MPs worry she is actually weak, vacillating and inarticulate.We are becoming accustomed to ruthless “wet jobs” by authoritarian tyrannies such as Russia, North Korea and the People’s Republic of China, many of them “friends” of Jeremy Corbyn.But Saudi Arabia has always revelled in public and private bloodshed. When it comes to terrorism, all roads lead back to Riyadh.A respectable MP, who does not joke about such matters, tells me the Saudi Embassy in London once had a torture chamber in the basement.I wonderit still does Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tories need to stand behind pm
story: On Wednesday, she flies to Brussels for the European Council summit.With mounting Cabinet unease over the prospect of a Customs Union fudge, it is, as one Government source puts it, “squeaky bum time”.Four potential ministerial resignations loom over fears Britain could be tied to a permanent Customs Union. And Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson and Scottish Secretary David Mundell could resignNorthern Ireland is granted special status in any EU deal.The DUP and Remain Tory MPs also threaten Mrs May’s survival.Brexit chief Dominic Raab flew to Brussels yesterday for last-ditch talks. Cutting it will make holidays cheaper for families who have been hit by pricier trips because of the weaker Pound.On long haul flights, there is a £ tax on an economy ticket. This is a huge leap from  when it was just £.There is no environmental justication, it is simply used to fill the Treasury’s coffers. Slashing it will also boost businesses hoping to sell products outside of the EU.It will show Brexit Britain is an outward-looking, global nation.We hope you’re listening, Mr Hammond.JEREMY Kyle was inspired to see a doctor after reading a Sun article about testicular cancer.Before that, the TV favourite had been hesitant to seek advice after he found a lump.One in  blokes will have testicular cancer in their letime. title: this is your brexit boudicca moment theresa its time to say on your way barnier like up yours delors
story: I could see where he was going with this. After all, as we remember from school, this ancient British queen rose up against the Roman Empire, winning battles, slaughtering enemies and forcing the Romans to contemplate leaving Britain all together.“But, hang on,” I replied. “Wasn’t Boudicca eventually defeated ”Whatever the details, my friend was right. It is time for Theresa May to call on her deepest reserves of defiance and stand up to the European Union.Brussels has rejected her Brexit proposals, insulted us at the recent Salzburg summit and wants to dismember the United Kingdom by effectively annexing Northern Ireland for itself.Theresa May’s respect towards the EU has been met consistently with contempt for Britain. She has wished Brussels every success, while they wish us nothing but failure and decline. She has suggested solutions while they point out problems. And she has taken her Government to the brink by proposing a future relationship that is hated by many of her own MPs and supporters.It is time, now, to stop.Her Chequers plan already goes too far. It would tie us to European laws, over which we would have no say, and force us to accept the rulings of the European Court of Justice.It would prevent us from taking our own decisions and making our economy more competitive. And it almost certainly stops us from striking our own trade deals.Worse still,the Government persists with Chequers, we will end up with something even worse: Chequers Minus, which could mean making annual payments to Brussels, complying with more EU laws and accepting liberal immigration rules that amount to continued free movement.The longer we pretend Chequers can survive, the worse the outcome will be. As we negotiate the Withdrawal Agreement, Britain should be seeking watertight assurances about our future relationship. Without them, we will sign away a £billion orce payment without any confidence we will get a fair deal for the future.But the crisis the Prime Minister described to Parliament yesterday, and which the Cabinet will discuss today, is not about Chequers, but the so-called “backstop” — what should happen to Northern Irelandthere is no eventual agreement on the future relationship.The EU’s proposition is an outrage. If there is no deal on the future relationship, they expect Northern Ireland to remain inside the Customs Union and, in effect, the single market.That would mean, in trying to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic, we would create a hard border between Northern Ireland and Great Britain. That’s right, a border within our own country to avoid having one with another.The backstop would mean politicians in the Republic have a say over laws in Northern Ireland, while politicians in Belfast and London would have none. And it effectively breaches the Good Friday Agreement, which demands that Northern Ireland’s place in the United Kingdom is respected unless a majority of Northern Irish people vote for the reunication of Ireland.The one concession the EU seems willing to make is that the whole of the United Kingdom can remain inside the Customs Union, not just Northern Ireland.But it insists there can be no time limit, and no right for the UK to unilaterally withdraw from the backstop.In other words, we would be trapped inside the Customs Union — following laws over which we have no say, letting Brussels grant trading access to our market for other countries and leaving us unable to agree trade deals of our own — for ever.This, of course, has always been the EU’s game. They have cynically used the Northern Irish peace process to try to tie the whole of the United Kingdom to the EU’s rules and regulations. And in their naivety, our negotiators have walked straight into the trap.The PM needs to tell the EU to get stuffed. And she must go back to the drawing board. She must replace Chequers with an ambitious, Canada Plus, free trade agreement between the UK and the EU. She must insist that the Northern Irish solution lies with technology and policy that avoid checks at the border. And she must tear up the backstop.One alternative, still a compromise for Brexiteers like me, is to agree that the UK will remain inside the Customs Union for a period of up to five years while the appropriate systems are put into place.Critics will say the EU will never agree. Butthey cannot accept a trade deal consistent with their principles and which respects the integrity of their single market, we know they seek only a damaging deal for Britain, or no deal at all.Others will say the Government could not get this kind of plan through the Commons. But it stands a better chance than Chequers Minus.This was, in fact, the plan Theresa May first set out at Lancaster House in January .There, she warned against a Chequers-style deal, saying: “We do not seek to hold on to bits of membership as we leave” and “we will not have truly leftwe are not in control of our own laws”.And she warned against what the backstop demands. She insisted on creating “no new barriers to living and doing business within our own Union”, and warned against “an unlimited transitional status”, which she called a “kind of permanent political purgatory”.Instead, she sought “a comprehensive free trade agreement” and the freedom for “Britain to negotiate its own trade agreements” with other countries.In other words, she described the Canada Plus agreement that is prepared and drafted but gathering dust inside the Brexit Department.Many years ago, The Sun advised us to say “up yours, Delors” to a meddling European Commissioner. Today, the PM needs to find her inner Boudicca and say: “On your way, Barnier.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: royal wedding princess eugenie wedding soap opera
story: Too much décolletage or, God forbid, a side split and one risks what has now become known in common parlance as “doing a Raquel Welch”, who didn’t so much upstage the bride at her son’s ­wedding as eclipse her completely.And so, paralysed by the uncertainty of it all, the majority of “immediate family” wedding snaps feature the loving couple, a couple of blokes chilling in their usual suits, and two middle-aged women looking deeply uncomfortable in unforgiving taffeta and a hat that resembles an upturned lamp shade.Or, in Sarah Ferguson’s case, a titfer reminiscent of a stewardess for a s Eastern Bloc airline. Then, to keep up appearances for the family photo, Sarah had to hover nervously behind the gimlet-eyed former father-in-law who has ignored her for the past  years.But worst of all, she had to stand by and watch Prince Harry and his glossy new we sweep in and steal bride Eugenie’s thunder with news of their impending baby.A child, I might add, with the added sting of bumping the bride and her sister Beatrice even further down the line of succession.Far from feeling like a “royal wedding”, it bore all the hallmarks of a Hello! or OK!-funded celebrity shindig, or worse, an excerpt from US prime-time soap opera The Royals, starring Elizabeth Hurley.Take the, er, crowds gathered outside Windsor’s St George’s Chapel.“Who are you hoping to catch a glimpse of ” asked a TV reporter.“George Clooney,” came the cheerful reply.Someone  was hoping for David Beckham. They got neither.Both couples claimed other commitments but, given that they all took centre stage at Harry and Meghan’s nuptials and the Beckhams also made the cut for William and Kate’s big day, perhaps they felt this wasn’t A-list enough Instead, we had to make do with, among others, models Naomi Campbell, Cara ­Delevingne and Kate Moss, X Factor judges Robbie Williams and Ayda Field, and actresses Demi Moore and Liv Tyler.Some of whom uploaded gushing videos from the event and Instagram photos of their outfits with hashtag plugs for ­ious clothing brands.At a “royal” wedding  The notoriously traditional Queen Mother must be turning in her grave.There will be the modernisers within the palace walls who regard this as “progress” for a monarchy that, as they see it, must appeal to a younger generationit is to survive.But to my mind, it’s the complete opposite.The pomp, ceremony, tradition, duty and, most importantly, ­mystique of the royals is what sustains them.This wedding — between a “Princess” who performs no royal duties and her Jack of tequila trade — has shone a ­spotlight on the blindingly obvious threat that, once the dutul Queen and Prince Philip are no longer with us, the ­“modern” monarchy will continue to make ever decreasing circles until the taxpayer finally decides, “Hang on — they’re just like us” and the game will be up.With this #royalwedding where even the bride’s mother, left, Instagrammed a designer plug “for my amazing dress” that threat has just come one step closer.RITA ORA is promoting her new album Phoenix. “It’s my first global release of an album.I’m really excited to express my music to the world,” she says.But why the seemingly ­regular need to, er, express her breasts at the same time After all, Ed Sheeran has never posed in just his kecks and he’s sold  squillion records.ANGRY passengers on a flight from London Heathrow to Istanbul intervened to stop Home Office officials from deporting Somalian Yaqub Ahmed.“I know he’s scared,” protested one, before leading a chant of: “Take him off the plane, take him off the plane.”Though probably not as scared as the -year-old girl who was gang-raped in London by Ahmed and two of his equally unsavoury friends – the crime for which he was being deported before these witless do-gooders stepped in.Pitully, the officials capitulated and Ahmed is still in this country awaiting our next move.Meanwhile, as some of the passengers virtue-signalled their liberal credentials by posting footage of the showdown, perhaps they could now be identied and charged with obstructing the course of justice Or, at the very least, be asked to welcome the delightful Mr Ahmed into their own homes until such time as his removal can be rearranged Let’s seetheir liberalism extends to putting their own teenage daughters at risk.PIZZAS and pies must shrink to tackle obesity, claim new official guidelines from Public Health England.Sigh. Amazing, isn’t it, how millions of people manage to stay slim by eating healthily and doing moderate exercise while advocating the same mindset to their children Radical, I know, buta pizza is large, how about sharing it Or perhaps not buying it at all Or is a slice of personal responsibility too hard to swallow CHANNING Tatum and Jessie J are dating.We know this because they’ve been spotted ­laughing together at a mini-golf course.Ah yes, those heady, early months of dating when you’re presenting the best side of yourself and pretending you just love doing kooky stuff like ­hitting a ball into the clown’s mouth or paddling in pointless circles around the local ­boating lake.Then the eager-to-please phase passes and, before you know it, you’re watching ­separate TV shows in dferent parts of the house. And what a blessed relief it is too.QUESTION Time is holding a series of auditions for potential David Dimbleby replacements such as Kirsty Wark, Emily Maitlis, Nick Robinson and Julie Etchingham.They are each chairing a  of politicians and journalists in front of a live audience – the only dference being the programmes won’t be broadcast.Meaning that every last one will be far better than the real thing where, with a few notable exceptions, participants now sanitise their every utterance for fear of being publicly mauled by the kangaroo court of social media.GWYNETH  Paltrow and her new husband Brad Falchuk now refer to them- selves as “The Faltrows”. Let’s just hope that German ice skater Paul Boll doesn’t take a shine to Jane Horrocks.THE SUN has ­partnered with the Movember Foundation to help raise funds and awareness for men’s health issues by ­encouraging people to grow a sponsored ­moustache.Count me in.Post-menopause, this is the look I’m aiming for.AN “invisible” super-yacht has been invented for ­billionaires who value their privacy.Costing £million, it is coated in mirrored glass which, according to the designer, makes it “disappear between water and sea”.Er, doesn’t that mean other vessels will smash into it Still, at least it will sink ­privately. KATE SILVERTON asks her six-year-old daughter each day: “How did you fail today ”The Strictly contestant, who advocates taking kids outside their comfort zone by trying boxing or climbing, adds: “You are not ­trying hard enoughyou haven’t failed.”Perhaps give skying a miss though, eh ANT McPARTLIN and estranged we Lisa ­Armstrong received their decree nisi yesterday.Meaning that in six weeks’ time, the petitioner can apply for the decree absolute as long as everyone is agreed on the ision of cash and assets.In other words – as anyone who’s orced will know – this is when the arguments really begin.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour remainers back john bercow over brexit
story: An official inquiry condemned him and his regime for a hideous culture of sex harassment and intimidation going back years. Two bullying accusations, which he denies, are levelled at Bercow.In any other organisation he would already have been suspended or fired. But Labour need this supposedly impartial Speaker to help stop the ­referendum verdict being enacted and perhaps set up another vote.Bercow, incredibly, wants a NEW bullying inquiry. title: brexit deal latest there may britain could stay tied to eu another year
story: Addressing the  national bosses at a tense summit in Brussels last night, the PM told them she is “ready to consider” extending the  month transition period after the UK leaves the EU next March.The potentially incendiary move has been drawn up by the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier to try to end a bitter impasse over the Irish border.It would mean abiding by all Brussels rules until December  at the earliest,  months longer than No’s current transition plan.And that would include continuing free movement of all migrants, as well as the UK having to fork out another £bn into EU coffers in fees, while having no say in any Brussels decision making.The PMs high stakes play runs the risk of infuriating hardline Brexiteers who have long opposed keeping any ties to the EU beyond Brexit day on March , let alone for almost three more years.An EU official told reporters after Mrs Mays speech: She said the UK would be ready to consider the extension of the transition period.European Parliament President Antonio Tajani, who was also invited to listen to the PM’s  minute address, confirmed her signicant move.MEPs’ boss Mr Tajani said of the summit discussion: “Both sides mentioned the idea of an extension of the transition period as one possibility which is on the table and would have to be looked into.Downing Street had earlier insisted a transition extension was “not something we are calling for”.But Mrs May herself refused a point blank chance to rule it out, ducking a direct question from ITV News on her arrival in Brussels.Mrs May left the dinner after her half-hour speech, as the other  leaders enjoyed a meal of turbot cooked in beer.But Tory MPs lined up to slap down her suggestions just minutes later.Brexiteer Nadine Dorries said thatshe was suggesting a transition extension, she should step aside - and slammed the billions that could now be spent paying more to the EU.Its time to stand aside and let someone who can negotiate get on with it and deliver. I fully support DD [David Davis] as interim leader, she added.Andrea Jenkyns agreed, telling ITVs Peston: It’s ludicrous that it’s two years on and we haven’t got a deal. Extending [the transition] just kicks it into the long grass.And John Redwood said her plans would be unacceptable, saying: I dont think MPs would vote for it.Nigel Farage added: This is another betrayal of Brexit... I dont think she can survive this.He speculated it could mean British taxpayers having to pay an extra £BILLION to the EU.But Tory Deputy Chairman James Cleverly played down the suggestion of extending the transition period - pointing out that it was only a proposal from the EU.He refused to rule it out, but said Michel Barnier put forward a proposal which our Prime Minister and negotiating team will think about.The PM also held separate meetings with Donald Tusk, Jean-Claude Juncker, Emmanuel Macron and Irish PM Leo Varadkar today.But despite the high level talks, EU leaders said tonight that despite intensive negotiations there had not been enough progress between negotiators to come to a deal.They said that a November summit was off the cards for now, but stood ready to hold a December one in the hope that a deal could be sealed there instead.No had already given up any hope of forging a orce deal at the summit before it even started.The Brexiteer called the EU “a gravy train soaking us dry”.It had been billed as the “moment of truth” for an agreement before last weekend’s big row.Mrs May also asked the leaders to show “courage” to help her break the impasse.And despite talks stalling over Ireland yet again when a deal brokered by bureaucrats collapsed on Sunday, she also insisted an agreement was possible and appealed for them to come up with “creative” ways to help her.Mrs May told the leaders: We have shown we can do dficult deals together constructively. I remain confident of a good outcome.The last stage will need courage, trust and leadership on both sides.After she delivered the pitch, Mrs May was then asked to leave the summit room so her fellow national could deliberate over her words with dinner.The PM ed to the UK Representative to the EU’s official residence in Brussels for dinner alone with her aides.Under Mr Barnier’s proposal to extend the transition period, Mrs May must inagree to keep the whole of the UK in an indefinite customs union as a backstop to keep the Irish border opentrade talks to deliver another solution fail.But Mrs May has already ruled that out, and Cabinet ministers have demanded a legally binding mechanism to ensure any backstop is only temporary.Ireland’s Taoiseach Leo Varadkar gave his backing to the extension as one way of breaking the Irish border deadlock, but only under Mr Barnier’s conditions.Mr Varadkar said: Any extension to the transition period couldnt be a substitute for the backstop.We would still need to have that, but perhaps it would allow people to have greater confidence that it would never need to be invoked.”Some EU leaders began to express open doubts that Mrs May will ever be able to strike a deal with them because of Tory party turmoil over Brexit.Lithuanian president Dalia Grybauskaitė: We do not know what they want, they do not know themselves what they really want - thats the problem.“If you have on the other side of the table a negotiator who has no strong mandate, its very dficult to negotiate.”Ms Grybauskaitė, dubbed her country’s own ‘Iron Lady’ because of her black belt in karate, added: “The Brits must decide finally want they want, and rally behind the Prime Minister and not split, not battling, to have a joint opinion and joint stance.”But other EU leaders were more optimistic, including France’s Emmanuel Macron who said the EU would “find deals” to secure an orderly Brexit.The French president last night emerged as a key figure of support for Mrs May to break the Ireland impasse, having lead the way in torpedoing her trade deal proposals at a summit in Salzburg last month.Mr Macron was one of four EU leaders that Mrs May held one-to-one meetings with in Brussels ahead of the summit’s start.Another pivotal player, Germany’s Angela Merkel, was also supportive, saying: “We want good relations with Britain.“We would have been happythe exit deal was ready. Instead, we are  percent there.But I will tackle the issues in good spirit and try everything to find an agreement.”It also emerged tonight that Mrs May has invited  chief executives to take part in a conference call on Friday to brief them on the status of Brexit negotiations.The invitations, which were sent out today, are part of efforts by Downing Street to build a closer relationship with business.And in a blow to the PM, French officials today published a paper stating that in a No Deal scenario, British visitors to France would in principle need a visa to enter the country, and would be considered illegal immigrantsthey failed to apply for one.The document also revealed that French ministers are planning to implement new border checks the day after Brexitthe two sides fail to agree a deal.Its the first time a major European country has publicly announced plans for how it would cope with a No Deal outcome.On a crucial day in the Brexit process:At the start of todays summit, some leaders expressed optimism about the chances of a deal - Dutch PM Mark Rutte said: Im cautiously optimistic that over the coming weeks Michel Barnier and the negotiating team in the UK will come to conclusions.Angela Merkel claimed a deal was  per cent done, adding: I’m approaching this with the spirit of always trying to do everything to find an agreement.But Lithuanias president Dalia Grybauskaite said the UK had yet to agree its own negotiating position.She said Britain needs to rally behind the Prime Minister all together and not split - to have a joint opinion and joint stance.And chief negotiator Michel Barnier added: We are not there yet. Brexit must be orderly for everyone and for all the issues, including on the island of Ireland.So we need time, we need much more time, and we will continue to work in the next weeks calmly and patiently.Belgiums Charles Michel said: We are concerned because we see it is dficult in the British Parliament to have the same views on the future of the relationship between the EU and UK.The EU meeting which started today was previously earmarked as the moment when leaders would sign off an a withdrawal agreement.But talks broke down over the weekend after the EU insisted on a border backstop which could carve off Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.Mrs May told a Cabinet meeting yesterday that she wont accept any deal which which breaks up the Union - or which keeps Britain tied to the EU customs union permanently.And speaking to MPs in the Commons today, the PM said: We continue to work for a good deal with the European Union - a deal that delivers on the Brexit vote but also a deal that protects jobs and livelihoods and crucially that protects the precious Union of the United Kingdom.We will not accept any proposals which would effectively break up the United Kingdom.She accused Jeremy Corbyn of preparing to betray voters by laying the ground for a second referendum on Brexit.Mrs May also rejected the Labour leaders claim that her Chequers proposals are dead after she failed to mention them by name in two recent speeches.Today Michael Gove suggested that a deal might not be signed until December - title: brexit deal latest theresa may says plan to keep britain tied to eu is only a matter of months as tory vultures circle

story: Meghan-mania hit the Victorian capital as the royal couple continued on their tour around Australia - but it was Harry that left one fan in tears with excitement as she scored a hug from the -year-old prince.India Brown, , was overwhelmed when Harry spotted her sign saying: “Been here since am, loved you since I was .The teen burst into tears as the prince gave her a hug, said to have told her: You are going to get me in trouble.Its another busy day for the expectant parents, who have so far seen their namesake koalas in Sydney and got a taste of rural le in Dubbo during their -day whirlwind tour of Australia.And the couple seemed delighted as they got the chance to visit an Australian beach to learn about its sustainability program and chat with lesavers about their work.The pair were seen laughing with the brightly dressed workers, with one leguard later saying: We asked themthey were going to go for a swim today but we all decided it was a bit too chilly.Maybe another time when theyre down here.Meghan was seen chuckling at the suggestion, telling the group: Maybe not today.The royal couples reluctance could be put down to the overcast Melbourne day, with the pair both wearing jackets as they hit the beach.Meghan arrived in Melbourne wearing a navy dress by Aussie designer Dion Lee and a Martin Grant trench coat while Harry was pictured in a dark jacket.The outfit showed off her growing pregnancy bump after the couple announced they were expecting their first child just days ago.The new royal remained sensible for the beach visit - swapping into flat eco-friendly shoes made from recycled water bottles by Rothys.Prince Harry and his we had caught the tram to the beach where they were peppered with questions from local students - which even includedthey had chosen a baby name yet.But Meghan remained tight-lipped on any possibilities, saying: Weve been given a long list of names from everyone, were going to sit down and have a look at them.The couple arrived late to their first engagement of the day after reportedly getting stuck in traffic, but their delayed arrival did not damper their excited welcome.The duchess was even presented with a tiara by an Albert Park Primary school student, with locals have waited from as early as am to catch a glimpse of the royals.The duke picked out Annie from the crowd after seeing her holding a bunch of flowers and toy tiara.Are they for her , he asked, gesturing towards his pregnant we.Meghan then came over, took the gts and said: Oh my goodness, thank you. Those are amazing.Harry also got a smile at the school when he was given the opportunity to name the pet snail, and suggested Speedy.As the couple left, one little boy told Harry: You remind me of my uncle.The duke replied: Is that a good thing  Is it because Ive got a ginger beard The expectant parents stopped to play with five-and-a-half-month-old Harriet Bonaddido and chatted with her mum Jessica during their walkabout.The -year-old said: As soon as I introduced my daughter to Harry, he said thats a great name.Maybe they will choose it for their own child, which would be fun.Meghan was right behind him and was playfully tickling her toes and said how sweet it was that Id brought her out today.Other signs including Worth the detention and Fresh Prince with red hair were held aloft to the party, who made their way through the Royal Botanic Gardens to Government House.Meghan was also keen to try out Australian Rules, taking the footy and giving it a punt to one of the women during a display from Victorias This Girl Can empowerment campaign.After tossing the ball, she laughed, saying: Im not sure I did it right!Jerril Rechter, chief executive of VicHealth, who showed Meghan around the event, said: She did pass an AFL football. She did a handball. Thats a pretty incredible thing for anybody to do.She had not seen an AFL football before Howard, the governors husband, explained to her what it was like - the weight of it is a little bit dferent, and that you handball it, you dont pass it.The duchess is said to have told kids she didnt have much spare time but she enjoyed relaxing and watching TV shows.But the former Suits star reportedly hesitated when asked what her favourite show was - saying: Theres heaps, I cant think of one.The Duke and Duchess are partway through a -day tour, during which they will see the Invictus Games and travel to New Zealand, Fiji and Tonga.Earlier today Meghan was caught on camera jumping in fright at a backfiring toy F car.The Duchess of Sussex was racing the models at a demonstration in Melbourne, when a loud bang made her flinch in fear.After landing in Melbourne for day three they were met by a crowd nearing , and abandoned their strict scheduling to meet royal fans for  minutes.Gts, including toys, flags and flowers, were given to the parents-to-be as a group began to sing Stand By Me, the gospel song performed at the royal wedding in May.One of the larger presents of the day came from Courtney Pistone, , who held a large teddy over the barriers and handed it to Meghan for the unborn baby.She said: I gave it to her for the nursery.I thought it would be suitable because we didnt knowit was a boy or a girl and both boys and girls like bears.The couple also got a taste of Australia as chargrilled kangaroo was on the menu for lunch as they visited restaurant Charcoal Lane.The restaurant, in the hip Fitzroy area of the city, served up an entree of mushroom and quinoa nest and chargrilled kangaroo and main courses of wild boar, saffron risotto and barramundi.It was prepared by chefs who were trained by the Mission Australia programme, which assists young indigenous Australians into employment.October They were greeted with hugs and flowers as they arrived in Dubbo just days after announcing they were expecting their first child in spring next year.Meghan is said to have told royal fans she was running on adrenaline as the couple fit in  engagements in  days.The Duke of Sussex said he and his we could not think of a better place to announce the upcoming baby than Australia.
